title: Analyzing Expert Behaviors in Collaborative Networks

author: Huan Sun, Department of Computer Science, University of California, Santa Barbara

segmentation: Hi Ron, good afternoon.
Welcome to my talk.
My name is Winston from UC Santa Barbara.
Today I'm going to talk about the analyzing expert behaviors in collaborative networks, so this is joint work with Doctor Medaka, Servicea from IBM Research.
My lab mates show long time Young Lee and Doctor Lawrence Kaplan from Army Research Lab and Doctor Shootout from IBM and my advisor professor system, yeah?
So.
Collaborative networks is a special type of social networks where members in this collaborative network jointly work with each other to complete specific tasks.
So specifically, 1 task words.
First initiated or started from one member here and then subsequently routed through the network until being resolved.
There are many examples of collaborative networks in real life, such as in ticket ticket processing in customer centers where we have the resolution records of different.
Now problematic is reported by customers and another example is the open source software development website, where have where we have the resolution records of a box.
So there is a.

Signific difference between traditional social networks and collaborative networks in terms of information flow, so information flow in traditional social networks is basically about information differing where the goal is to try to defeat the information or propagate the information to as many people as possible.
However, the increase in collaborative networks, the information flow is actually about information routing, where the goal is to find the right person to.
To complete a specific task instead of to influence others are propagated the information.
So, under this collaborative network setting, what we want to do is we want to analyze the following questions first.
How do experts in this collaborative network make routing decisions?
Are there any routing patterns when they transfer the tasks?
Second, who have made inefficient routing decisions so that the task transferred by those experts still need a lot of more experts to get it resolved and the customers get a lot of?
Complaints on that and 3rd how to optimize the routing performance of the network through, for example, providing targeted expert training to those inefficient experts.
And 4th, can we predict the completion time of a task before hand?
So that we can take early actions for those very difficult tasks.
So before we introduce our method to deal with those problems, let me first show several hours.
Visions we have made from our datasets.
So our first observation says that their tasks with similar content but very different routing sequences.
For example, these two problem tickets are from IBM IT service Department.
So this observation shows that a lot indecision is not a deterministic one given the task and we need a probability model to model the routing decision or the the process.
How about, uh, an expert to make to decide where to transfer the task.
Our search our second observations at that an expert might not always make the wise decision, that is, he might not might not directly send a task to the final resolver.
Let's check this example.
So the task words started from the expert EI and then routed through the network until result get arriving at the final result for UK here.
However, if we carefully look at the structure here, they expertly I could potentially directly send their task to Ek.
However, he didn't do that.
Why is that?
Is it because he does not understand the task very well?
That's randomly distributed, or he believed that the other expert, particularly e.g.
Here, has a better chance to solve their task or has a better chance to find the right expert to solve the task.
So, although it's very difficult to analyze the routing decision order decision process of the expert based on this single task is possible to analyze his routing patterns based on 10s of tasks.
Those experts has have dealt with or have transferred are resolved.
Our third of.
Observation is actually very exciting.
One which says that expert tends to transfer to transfer a task to another expert whose expertise is neither too similar, not too different from his own.

That is, again not necessarily the final resolver, so we make this observation by plotting the relative expertise difference between a task sender Anna Tasker's over, and actually we find that when the the relative expertise difference between two experts for the into.
This range then basically the task would be transferred more frequently among between those those two experts.
So we try to explain this phenomena in terms of two aspects.
On the one hand, if two experts expertise are two similar.
Basically, if one expert could not solve the task, then the other would not either.
So the 2nd.
If two experts expertise are two different than they might know each other's domain very well.
They might not have very frequent communications that few tasks would be transferred between them.
So based on these three observations we try to build our own model to capture those observations.
Now let's discuss how.
To build our model to model their decision process of the expert.
So we assume that when I ask for transfers a task he has to go through two phases in the first phase of course has to establish a candidate pool.
That is, he has to decide a set of experts he can.
He can potentially transfer the task to and in the second phase he will decide to transfer the task to a specific expert from the candidate pool based on some.
Patterns.
So.
So.
Let us first discuss the first one.
Space one we actually developed two routing strategies in the establishment of the candidate pool that our first task, neutral routing and the 2nd is called.
The task specific routing.
So in the task neutral routing we mean that the expert will not consider their specificity of the task being transferred.
That is, he will just blindly treat all their tasks the same.
By that we mean that he will include other neighbors.
That is other experts he has previously contact contact in their candidate pool and for task specific routing.

Actually the expert will do more rational analysis by analyzing who can potentially solve their task and then limit those expert he thinks could be possibly to solve their tasks in their candidate pool.
So those are two routing strategies we have developed.
Now let's discuss how to decide the candidate pool in the task specific routing.
We need to estimate The Who can solver, who can solve the task.
Basically we need to estimate the expert expertise and also the capability based on the tasks he has resolved.
He has solved before.
Particularly, we build a logistic model where we try to associate the task.
This word, description vector and also the expertise vector for each expert to predict the probability.

For each expert to solve their task, and in this model we will by using the historical records of the experts of the expert, we tried to estimate the parameters in the model and also the expertise vector for each expert.
So now.
Are we decide how to establish the candidate pool?
Now, let's discuss how to specifically select one expert from the candidate pool.
Of course, there are several basic patterns.
For example, we can just randomly select one expert from the candidate pool with an equal probability or second, we can use.
We can just select one expert from the candidate pool with some probability proportional to the number of tasks dispatched from one expert to another.

This is a try to mimic their situation that different experts might have a different capacity to deal with the tasks, and an expert might send more tasks to those experts with larger capacity or either certain pattern we tried to characterize their our observation we have we have discussed before we call it expertise difference.
So we try to use a lognormal distribution to describe their distribution of the relative expertise relative expertise difference.

Between our task sender Anna Tasker receiver and we use the lognormal density to describe the general trend of sending a task from from one expert to another given their relative expertise difference, and then we select one candidate, one expert from the candidate pool with probability proportional to this lognormal density.
So those are three basic patterns.
After to select one specific expert from the candidate pool.
Given these three basic patterns and there are two routing strategies we describe, the earlier we totally generate the six particular routing patterns.
Next

We are going to combine these six routing patterns into a generative model, where we assume that the routing decision of an expert is generated through a mixture of these of six routing patterns in this generative model, there is a significant variable we call called mixture weights, where the mixture which they note the each experts private preferences over different routing patterns where we are going to utilize this variable to analyze which expert tends to.
To employ which kind of patterns?
So we try to solve the model by maximizing the likelihood of absorb observing other task transfer relationships in the training data through the efficient variational EM.
Now let me show some experimental results.
So we utilize three datasets of them are from IBM IT service Department.
Each data set is about some problems reported by customers on specific topics.
So on specific topics such as a database usage or operating system.
So we try to evaluate the model based on the task completion time, which is defined as the number of experts contact before a task it resolved.

Since our model is the generative model, we can generate a routing sequence for each task and then try to evaluate their or estimated completion time based on the expected number of experts needed to resolve a task, and then we try to compare the true completion time and the estimated completion time.
And then use some error measure to evaluate the difference.

So here comes the memories of the main result actually turns out that our model can make a very accurate accurate estimation here, and I need to point out that the task completion time is actually a very important task itself, because it's very important to predict a task completion time before hand so that one can take early actions for those very difficult tasks.
So.
So now we also compare the resolution efficiency of different routing patterns, and we partition those experts into two types.
One type is called experts fearing task mutual routing and the other is called experts, fearing task specific routing.
We do this partition based on their mixture weights on different routing patterns.
We evaluated the efficiency by checking the number of experts the remaining experts needed to resolve a task.
After an expert fearing a certain pattern transfers the task.
Basically, the more remaining number add remaining experts are needed, the less efficient the current expert is.
We find that after an expert furing the task specific routing transfer, the task.
Basically, in most cases only one expert is needed.
However, after expert filtering, task neutral routing transfer the task two or three more experts are needed.
So from this study we found that by using task specific task specific routing patterns are basically more efficient than task neutral.
Repeating patterns and this also implies that why some?
Experts are more efficient and why some experts are less efficient, basically because they tend to apply rely on different routing patterns.
So based on this analysis, suppose we are going to optimize their network by changing those inefficient experts behavior.
Suppose we have a limited budget and now we need to consider which experts should be trained first to adopt their efficient task.
Specific routing patterns and how much efficiency improvement can we expect.
There are several intuitive methods, such as we can do the experts election by random selecting one expert from the network, or we can just select the expert who transfers the most tasks.

Alternatively, we can use our map model to do the expert recommendation by first conducting the task routing on a training set of tasks and select one expert to change the behavior based based on the.
And lead to the most efficiency improvement.
So we can test these experts election on a GNU testing set of data sets.
It turns out that using our model to do the expert recommendation.
We can get a much larger efficiency improvement than the other three baseline methods.
This shows that our model can be used in reality to optimize their knew the collaborative networks.
So he.
Here comes our conclusion.

Basically the main idea in this paper is we want to understand an analyze, capture the real behavior of experts in collaborative networks, and by doing that we hope to optimize their collaborative networks and improve the efficiency.
With that, I'd like.
Thank you and take any questions, thank you.
